transcript.content: This is audible.
Hello, welcome to the third in this new series of the Ricky Gervais show with me, Ricky Gervais, Steven Merchant -
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington.
Alright?

We've had loads of emails. Thank you for those. Sorry we can't reply to them all personally, but keep them coming. Some interesting ones. There's one in particular here from a guy who says, "I see there is less swearing now you're charging for the podcast. Dumbing down already, question mark."
Yeah.
Well, interesting.
I don't know how that's dumbing down.
Well, no, not swearing. That's interesting. Not swearing is dumbing down. And also the fact that he's complaining that we're not swearing enough. What sort of a cunt would bother writing that email?
Don't know, mate. I don't know. But I know he's just some kind of fucking cocksucker.
What have you got, any?

Well now, of course, a couple of weeks back you gave the rather long winded but fascinating sort of brain teaser conundrum, philosophical question about the heaven and hell dogs. And there's been a number of responses to that.
I know, I know.
Explain your error.

Well, I've got it. I know. I realized as soon as we put it out there that I should have said assume no prior knowledge. Otherwise you can just say, hold up a cat and say, is this a dog? Or you can say, what's my name? But they don't know anything about you. That's the thing. They only know about their selves. And I should have said that.
Yeah. So are you willing to just now say that you've embarrassed yourself?
I've embarrassed myself. I should have said. Yeah, it's got to be about. It's only about the. You can ask questions.
Well, do you know what? It's a bigger man than many that can admit that.
Or a man that's banged to rights and obviously caught out and has no choice.

Well, it's quite interesting to wade through the emails and find out the kind of people that are listening, get a sense of the different listeners. And I know you, Rick, have met some of the big celebrity names that have listened to the show and it's sort of because you've actually met them, but now you've got celebrities who are just emailing themselves, emailing you, just letting us know. This one is from a guy called Aaron. He says, my name is Aaron Douglas and I play Chief Tyrol on TV's Battlestar Galactica. And he listens to the show in his trailer. Now, I don't watch Battlestar Galactic. I Hear it's very good but it's nice to know that -
I don't watch it. I don't watch any of those things. But that's.

But it's nice that Chief Tyrol. And for those of you that watch Battlestar Galactic, I'm sure that means something, but nice that he got in touch. But I'm just thinking, who would you. In an ideal world, Rick, who would be your ideal listener and celebrity listener?

Well, there's not so much celebrities for me. I like the idea that captains of industry or scientists or people actually doing something worthwhile are listening. That's what excites me, because they hear, you know, we've had a couple of emails from people who are doing, you know, PhDs and psychologists and that and that. And that excites me more. These academics are listening. I mean, who's the weirdest person who should have more time on their hands, you know? You know, Stephen Hawking. Imagine Stephen Hawking listening to this show. You know, he's putting together the, you know, the formulation for the universe, but he's gonna listen to a little bit of monkey news from Karl Pilkington.
Imagine Stephen Hawking emailing us@podcastrickyjavais.com I mean, that would just blow our minds, wouldn't it? Oh, that he's got time to do that. That he's got the inclination to bother doing that.

He's always online, though, isn't he? He's always hooked up, is he? He's got that little computer on. Why not? Sure. That's one of the perks. You can just bung an email out whenever I'm not having a go. I just mean that's what I'm thinking. He's sat there with his little computer. Out of all the people in the world to have a chat with. I'd probably like to have a chat with him about space and that, because I can't get my head around it.
Cole, you can't get your head around frozen foods. What a chance are you gonna have with the universe?

No, but just putting stuff out there, the. You know, I mean, it freaks me out when I'm. When I'm lying there in bed at night and I think about how this world. On Friday, right, I was in. Was in bed, Suzanne, and I said, could the world fall?
It's like something from chicken licking. Wow.
That's a hell of a bit of pillow talk. That.
Isn'T foreplay. Hell. God.
But. But I'd like to sort of have a chat with him, because I reckon he could put it in a way that I could understand it.
Oh, I wish an Inuit was listening.
Did I not tell you this?
We.
We've had an e. We had an email from an Inuit.
Really? Yeah, yeah.

I thought I'd mentioned this. Have we not mentioned this before? No, no, it was an email from a guy who said. I think. Well, I don't think he lives. He lives in Canada, I think, or somewhere else. I apologize for if I'm getting that wrong, but I think he told. He said he was half Inuit and he listens to the show.

Half Inuit. See, that's interesting because I think I'm so remote. I know I'm probably wrong now, but I think those are so remote that I can't think where they're meeting people who aren't and who's going, you know, other societies are going, I'll tell you what, I'm fed up. There's no action. I'm going to the frozen tundra. I'm about to meet someone there. Do they do online dating?
Probably a lot of online stuff.
What'd you put as hobbies? Fishing?
Yeah. Skinning stuff.
Skinning stuff? Yeah. What stuffed your skin?
You know, seals.
Seals, yeah, sure. That's about it, isn't it?

Why are they hanging about around there? Why are seals going, you know what, it's cold, I'm sick of it here. It's windy all the time, what have you. And I'm getting a club on the head, do you know what I mean?
Yeah.
Because they're meant to be quite bright in terms of animals and that, aren't they? So why are they knocking about them parts?
I don't know.
Say, like if seals died out, right, would that be a problem?
We've done this, we've been through this before. Everything has a knock on effect.
Even a seal that's sort of in between something already. It's between a fish and a dog, innit?
I knew you were gonna say dog.
It's not between a fish and a dog. What do you think evolution does? Fish to dog? What do you mean it's between a fish and a dog?
I'm just saying it was a perfectly.
Evolved mammal that re entered the, the water, I imagine, and then got streamline and I mean, it's between a fish and a dog, but why not have.
One and the other? Why not have like, you know, you've got a dog, you've got a fish. Anything in the middle.
No, it's not between a fish and a dog. It's not between a fish and a dog. I don't know what "between" means. I don't know what-

This is it again about saving everything all the time. What is it doing? What's it doing? Everyone's feeling sorry for him all the time. Save the seal and all that. What's it doing? Why are we saving it? Let's just ask that question. What's it doing?
I don't know what to say. It's between a fish and a dog.
That bloke, the Eskimo who emailed in.
Inuit.
Would he be in a igloo thing?
Probably not, no.
Well, no, not- I mean, I don't think many igloos have got Internet capabilities, so I don't know. I don't want to slag them off.
But why aren't we saving them? Why aren't we helping-
Well when you build it, leave a little hole. That's where the, yeah.
But there's kind of igloo Internet cafes.
They all go to one igloo, yeah.
Yeah, but why, why are they being left alone to live like that when it isn't great?
What?

Well, we're always eager to help everyone in the world, aren't we? We're always, like going, oh, look, them people are fed up. Let's build the city up for them. Give them a, you know, coffee shop and all the rest of it. They're being left alone.
Frappuccinos for them.
They're being left alone in igloos and stuff.
Yeah.
Why isn't anyone saying-
But they're not asking for help. They're happy. Well, they're not necessarily happy, but that's the way they live. That's where they choose to live.
But why hasn't anyone just gone over and gone, you know what? We can make it a bit better for you.
Well, they have.
I've never had a leaflet through the door saying, help an Eskimo out. Or, you know, clothing for Eskimos.

The most remote people in the world, eventually someone gets them some whiskey and fags and that's the end of them as a culture. It happens all around the world. There can be this idyllic, idyllic world where there's no stress and soon they're watching Come Dancing on telly, knocking back some whiskey and smoking 40 fags a day.
But they're not moving are they?
Surely Dancing on Ice.

But what I mean is, like, Oxfam collects clothes for people in Africa where it's warm, probably don't need a jacket. Nothing for Eskimos where it's freezing, where they'd be quite happy to get a jumper in the post.
Right, okay, so what are you suggesting, to Africa we send parasols and sun cream?
Bikinis.
Yeah. (laughing) You're an idiot.
Out of all the people in the world to have a chat with, do you know, errm, what's his face? That German doctor.
Which one? The guy that displays the human body?
Guns someone. Guns Traben, or something.
Oh right, yeah.
Yeah, he's- he's pretty good. Mm. Just like the way, you know, he cuts stuff up. Shows you how the body works and that.
Sure.
And have you learnt anything from that?

Well, I don't, is he, is he a proper doctor? Because it's just that he's always- I mean, I could cut a body up. I never see him sort of put it back together. Is anyone keeping an eye on him sort of going, well, who is he?
Ricky laughs
I'm sure he's a proper doctor.
Well, well, he's-he sort of uh, sort of cuts bodies up on the telly and uh...sort of goes..here's...here's how like, intestines work or whatever.
Alright.

And he just uhh...he holds them up, fills them with food....uhhm and he goes "look, they got fatter". And uhh...I mean, he doesn't, he doesn't answer everything, like he doesn't say-I don't understand why...the intestines have to be...that long. I don't, I don't know why it just can't go from the throat, to the belly, exit. Straight ((dark?)) line down out the arse.
You must know.
Pause
Well, no, 'cause the way he-he dragged it out and it was like, miles long.
Yeah.
Pause
Pointless.
No it's not pointless.
Just-just have a, just have a straight, do you know what I mean, straight down--
It's to increase the surface area for absorption. So, a foot long intestine, you wouldn't absorb much food. Whereas, you go down, you know.
Yeah but just have more points in it where it has to go through some sort of filter.
What are you talking about? Again...the evolution sort of worked this out for us. It really works.
I don't think you're gonna improve on it. In your mind you-some kind of what, some kind of kerplunk style intestine--

No but what-what-what I mean is that's probably that long because years ago they were eating dinosaur and that might have took a lot of indigestion or something. I don't know how-how chewy it was. It might have been quite fatty, dinosaur meat, and it needs to go through all that. Now...we're eating like, yogurt.
Steve chuckles, Ricky laughs
So, I mean, we don't, we don't need anything, that, you know, is-is doing that much work anymore, all the food is mashed up. Auntie Nora, right?
Ricky suppresses laughter, Steve laughs slightly
All her food is mashed, right. She doesn't have to chew anymore. She's got teeth, but she doesn't need them. And that's how, how--
Ricky bursts into laughter
She's got teeth but she don't need 'em!
No, but that's how we're moving on.
(crosstalking) Well she could have her intestines removed then.
No, but this is what I'm saying--
(crosstalking) That would solve our other problem, wouldn't it.

We're changing everything all the time, aren't we? I mean, there's some fella who I was looking on the Internet. Uhh... identical twins, right? They were sort of sick of looking like each other. So they were like, what can we do? Right? And one of the twins said, "you have my arm", right?
Steve chuckles
And he, he had his arm taken off and stuck on his, his twin, so his twin's got like three arms.
No, it's not true.
Steve laughs
It's on the website.
No, it's not true.
What!? What, for a laugh, they were bored?
Inaudible crosstalk
What doctor's doing this then?
Well, they're old enough to sort of say, this is what we want, and--

No, no, no, no, no, no, no. Doctors don't go, "well, if he wants another arm and I'll take ((incoherent babble)) they don't, doctors don't do that. What sort of practice is this doctor going around and going--
Dr. Jekyll.
I mean, Karl, think of what you're saying.
No but--
--where would he have stopped? "Can you put his head on my knee?" "It's up to you!"
(laughing slightly) Yeah.
(in a voice) "You're paying!" "If you sign this, you-you may get my consent." Muuhhhh...
But-but we-you know, it is a ama--
What do you think these doctors sit around doing, playing Mr. Potato, what-what do you think these doctors are doing?
Just, they do as they're told.
They don't do as they're told.
They do if someone wants it, and-and twins, sort of, it can get you down, can't it? Being a twin... 'cause it's like--

--sorry, what would this SOLVE though? I thought you said he would-he-he gave one of them a-a bigger nose or a beard or...two front teeth to make him look different, right? Not "I'll tell you what we could do." "Go on." "Uhmm...would you like one arm?" "Go on, what are you thinking?" "Well... me three you one...therefore not twins."
Steve chuckles
Novelty.
I mean, you are a mental man.
But they can do it now, can't they? There's no sort of. There's no line drawn anymore. They don't go, you're crazy, we're not gonna do that.
Yeah, in saw, too. Not in the real world. They don't do things like this.
There's another bloke, right? I don't know the sort of full ins and outs of it.
Go on. You surprised me.

But what he asked for, something happened to his tackle, right? Yeah, right. So he was at the doctors and they were like, what can you do for Me, it's a bit embarrassing. I've got nothing down there. Right. So they were like looking at it, going, yeah, Doctor, I don't know if he started like rubbing his chin with his finger or something. Looked down, he's thinking, got an idea. You know, you've got a lot of fingers. How many of them do you use? The patient's like, yeah, I see what you're thinking. They cut off one of his fingers, sewn that onto where his tackle is, he's happy.
Well, that's different though, isn't it? That's where they've taken tissue. No, but I assume they fashioned it into more of a knob than a finger.
No, I still think it's there with like a little knuckle and, you know, fingernail and that.
Well, I assure you it isn't. They've probably used the finger as a basis to then build up some sort of knob based organ.
If you were doing that, use a sausage. I mean, why lose a finger?

Well, I'll tell you why. Because your finger has your tissue, your blood type and therefore would graft near your testicles. A sausage is a thing that's made by a butcher out of offal. Okay. That really can't be grafted onto any part of the human body. That's why they very rarely use any meat products in. I know, yeah. Use. Well, I mean, why not use a sausage? You're a mental case.

I, I saw some bloke the other day in a meeting and on his desk he had a picture of, of his kids who were twins, right. And they did, they looked alike and he did that thing of dressing them the same, that sort of thing that, you know, annoys me. And I sort of said, you know, you've only got a small desk, just have a picture of one of them. It looked at me like I was mental.
That's amazing.
It's not. I think it's a, you know, it's common sense.
You know what you come up with there? No solution to anything. That's what you've come up there. You've come up with the best no solution I've ever heard in my life.
Or it's solutions to problems that don't exist.
No, because more room on the desk, innit?
Yeah, yeah. It's no solution to a problem that didn't exist in the first place.

Well, there was a picture on the, When I was on the plane coming back from here, there was a picture of this new luxury hotel. It will be, I think, $10,000 a night to stay There it looked extraordinary. It was a hotel and the best rooms were built under the water, under the sea. So it was an amazing. The best hotel we've ever seen, but surrounded on all sides by glass and out of it you could see the sea, the sharks, the fish.
I don't think I'd like that.
No?

But again, that's just one of them hotels where it's...where it's over the top for over the top sake, innit? Like where they have 12 course meals. Well, just have two but make them bigger rather than dragging it out and there's..there's the first course, you know, a couple of, you know...
Snails.
Yeah, it's just...for me, all that...
Don't eat a snail, don't have one snail..have one...eat one big tortoise.
Steve laughs

If you want slow food, don't have loads of little snails. Here y'are, there's a giant tortoise tuck into that. Feeds 10. But..but..but it's what you're saying before, when you start having to take a risk with food, like the fish that can kill you if you eat it, don't bother. But it's apparently a delicacy in Japan. Again, someone could verify this where they a live little octopus. And it can stick to your throat because it's obviously fighting for its life. I mean, good. Again, you don't need to eat a live octopus. What are you thinking? How cruel is that?
Well, how fresh do you need your food?
Ricky laughs

It's just not, it's not, you know what I mean? But I always remember this story when I was a kid about some bloke who bit sad, the story, but weird. He had throat cancer, right, and his doctor said, carry on with your life, right, it's not going to be that good, but just carry on, but don't eat meat. And he was like, I love meat. He's like, yeah, but just don't, you know, have your veg, you know, plenty of vitamins and stuff. Keep yourself strong, but don't be eating that. Anyway, he was fed up because he loved his meat and his wife was feeling a bit sorry for him one day and thought, you know, I'm sick of him looking fed up and that. All he wants is some meat, for God's sake, give him some meat. So she goes to the butcher's, gets him a big piece of, like steak and what have you. He can't believe it. He's like, oh, brilliant. Cheers for that. Anyway, he's got the meat on his plate, just about to tuck in and the cancer comes out from his throat.
Ricky laughs
What?!
No, it's something...I know it sounds really weird, but it's something that I was told about years ago when I was growing up.
What are you talking about?
It was just some bad illness, some cancer thing, and it sort of. It was coming out, waiting for the meat.
Ricky and Steve laugh
I don't know what you're doing! Again, a lot of your medical knowledge is from....
..is from the film Alien.
So this guy with throat cancer, okay, as opposed to it being a disease of the cell...
It was like a living...
The alien.
Oh, it was...it was a...uh, it was the animal. It was the little animal cancer.
That's why he wasn't all...
What are you talking about?
That's why he wasn't allowed to eat meat.

So it's sitting there. So it's actually sitting there. And so I'll tell you what I'd have done if I'd have had some cancer in my life. I'd go *coughs*  There you go. What are you talking about? So what happened?
Erm...he choked to death on this thing and the wife was like, Oh, I shouldn't have given him the meat after all.
That's a bollocks story.
There's loads of weird stuff like that happens in medical stuff.
Well, the terrible thing is, if you got testicular cancer and you eat meat, your bollocks come out of your trousers and they're all over the plate and you have to be asked to leave the restaurant.
The other thing that I was told when I was younger about medical stuff and that, err...
Who's telling you this stuff?
Me mam. Me mam told me about it.
Jeez.
Because she always says to me, dad, because he has too much meat. And she's always like, you know, remember the fella..
Remember the fella with the troll in his throat
But erm...my gran, she had summat wrong with her eyes, and, they sort of took them out and they were just dangling on a cheek and she could still see through them. They were operating on her.
They would have, yeah.
They sort of say..
No, no, no, no. She wouldn't have been conscious, though.
No they were then.
Oh yeah?
Something to do with the eyes. And it's like..
No
No, it's no good operating on eyes if your eyes are asleep.
What do you mean your eyes are asleep?
It's like a heart, isn't it? You want to keep them awake. No you keep the eyes open.
What do you mean, you want to keep them awake? What heart surgery is where blokes awake? Stop talking shit all your life.
What I mean is, they don't stop the heart.
Course they don't stop your heart because it kills you.
Yeah, I know. So what I mean is, it's like the eyes, they wanted to make sure they were working. So the...the only way to do it is keep her awake.
No, it's not because you don't know whether they're working or not. You can't see what she sees. What you think you can plug something in and see what people are thinking?
It was something like...
No, no, it wasn't something like that.
Well, she could see. She said it was really weird. How, like, you know, you can see...
She could see her knees.
Ricky laughs
That is bollocks.
Oh, chimpanzee that!  He's only gone written it down, the little.....

That's the jingle for Karl's diary, excerpts of which we read each week. Get straight into it. A band from the Conga have won the best newcomers in a Radio 3 competition. They use pots and pans for instruments. It says that the Conga is a poor sad place. So why do people do that happy dance at the end of parties called The Conga?
Right.  One, it's the Congo. There's no place called the Conga.
Steve laughs
They come from a place called the Congo. Where do you come from? Okey Cokey. It's a terrible place. We don't know whether to put our left leg in or our right leg in. Sometimes we shake it all about.
We're not sure if we should, but...
Ricky laughs
Conga! Fucking hell! You're such a..

Went into the gadget shop today. It's full of stuff that we don't need. Gadget used to be a good word that made you think of James Bond with all his gadgets. The best thing I could find in the shop was a clock that ran on potatoes.
Ricky laughs
We are definitely going backwards
I agree. Well, what's the...Who cares about that little electrical impulse? So what?
Had a night out with old schoolmate. Found out about more of the other lads I went to school with. One is living underground.
Ricky laughs
What do you mean, living underground? Not like a mole. Do you mean he's got a basement or do you mean he digs a hole every night?
My mate went to visit him and he said it's all..it had been raining really heavily and that, and it's all the rains running...
What do you mean he went to visit him? He went down here. What's that? That's a hole in the ground. Yeah, come in. Cup of tea?
He just said, oh, come. Come round see us. And he's living underground.
What do you mean he's living underground?
He wanted to be in the army but was turned away. And that's the closest thing you can sort of-
How is that similar to li- being the army?
Oh, that's exactly like the army? Yeah, yeah. Where they teach you trades and, you know, engineering and flying.
I don't know. He's happy. He's happy down there. He said it was really muddy and what have you. He said he won't be going back to visit him.
What's he got down there?
Jus-, Just stuff. Just like a sleeping bag, a lamp.
He dug. He's dug himself a subterranean cave.
Near my old infant school. They knocked it down because it was like, a wreck. You'd be in the class and you could lean on the wall-
Yeah, some silence.
-*Unintelligible* would go through it and stuff. And um, they knocked it all down, and I think that's when he was at his most happy, this bloke.
I believe this though. I believe someone he went to school with now lives in a hole.

That doesn't shock me. Whether the tales I've heard of horses in houses and big headed kids with webbed hands and feet and you know, and him. I believe that someone he went to school with now lives in a hole. That isn't bizarre to me. That's-.
We've spent far too long with him if that. Now you're just happy to accept.
I totally accept that. I- I'd be surprised if I walked around where he lived that there weren't more people living in holes. His dad wanted to throw his budgie on the fire.
True.
His budgie died. His dad said let's throw it on the fire. I mean his mum. What did your mum do when your budgie died?
She just was worried about the other bird that was left. So she made it a bit of company by getting a rock, getting a feather off the dead budgie, sticking on the rock, putting it in the cage.
So a man living in a hole is not that bizarre? Alright, carry on.
I read me science magazine. Some things I learned from the science magazine. Number one, space is running out of space. We should stay out of the sea because shark attacks are up.
Yeah. Probably four a year now.
Well, he just says here we should just stop going in the sea. There's no need for it.
Exactly.
Why is there no need for going in the sea?

Just because there isn't now, is there? We've got loads of land. So just, you know, one or the other. We walked out the sea. This is what I mean about going backwards, getting back in it again. We came from the sea originally, now we're going back in it. Don't go in it, unless you're in a boat.
Rules. The rules according to Karl Pilkington.
The rules of Karl Pilkington.
Oh God.

Did the podcast and then went for a walk round Manchester Square. Years ago a woman lived round there who had a head like a pig. She was known as the Pig Woman of Manchester Square. That made me think, if there were other pig headed women knocking about London.
Do you know what I mean? Why was she nicknamed that? Why not just the pig headed woman? That suggests to me like there was loads of pig headed women and that's the one of Manchester Square.
Right...

Well, no, it was more to do with identifying her not amongst other pig headed women. But go; 'have you seen the Pig Woman. Of Manchester Square?'. IE, Go down there and see the Pig woman, It's in Manchester Square.
What happens if she's walked off from there though? And you go, well, no, but I saw one on New Cavendish Street.
She'll always come back if you rattle the feed.

Watch the film about Hitler. Didn't watch all of it as it was subtitled. Can't be doing with that. Ask Suzanne if cinemas are full of deaf people when they're showing subtitled films. She said, shh, I'm trying to watch it. I said, what do you mean shh? It's subtitled. I can make as much noise as I want.

Yeah, she's a lucky, lucky woman. You must be a joy to watch a subtitle film. I mean, the concentration is up there already. I mean, it is hard to concentrate. It's not as easy as when you're hearing it because you read things, but it's possible if you had a buffoon going, I'm just gonna sit here and make as much noise as I want. What's the point of that? What is the point of that? I mean, it's possible, but why do do that in a cinema? Just walk into a subtitle film, go, right, everybody, let's all do the conga.

Well, yeah, or during, during ballet, you know, I mean, ballet, they're just dancing. You don't need to listen to the words, just have a conversation. We're having our bathroom done. The bathroom man was round at 9 this morning. We weren't allowed to use the shower because it all had to be bone dry before we could use his waterproof filler. Not that waterproof. Then went for a brew with Ricky. We talked about monkeys and how they are closer to humans than they are to apes and how bees will drink cider to get off their heads now and again. There is a bee that lets the drinking get in the way of the work and other bees sting it to death. Blimey.

Yeah, well, there's bees. They love a drink and they can just. They will drink pure alcohol. They drink omnibus. They Drink ethanol, you know, I don't know why they love getting off it. And they fall down and they're drunk, right? A bee can take an equivalent like 20 liters of wine, right? But some bees get addicted in the same sort of percentage as human addiction. Like 10% of bees, they can't get enough. They take ethanol, they take cider apples and that. And then when they get back to the hive, they go in a bit pissed and they've got guard bees and they go, come on, we've all had a. Yeah, they sort of are, right? And they push them away and push them away again. Then the next time they go, right, I've had enough, and they give it a good hiding. And Carl couldn't get over this. I saw his face, but I. I knew that he was thinking of that bee with sort of like eyes rolling around his head, a little bit belligerent, with his jacket on backwards.
Yeah.
